metadata.case_name: Canara Bank Limited & Anr. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from orders dated March 16, 1962, and February 14, 1962 of the Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L.C.As. Nos. 212 of 1962 and 869-88 and 937-945 of 1961.
Respondent in Appeal No. 787 is a clerk employed by Canara Bank Limited at its Bandra branch since October 1953.

Respondent claimed special allowance of Rs. 15/- per month as cashier in-charge of cash in pay offices under para 164(b)(7) of Sastry Award; worked as such at Worli and Bandra branches, sole charge of handling cash, receiving and paying.
Employees of both banks filed applications under s. 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act, allowed by Labour Court.
Bank resisted: application not entertainable under s. 33C(2), no jurisdiction; not at pay office; not cashier in-charge as no employee solely in-charge, respondent routine clerk.
Labour Court found respondent sole paying and receiving clerk, relied on Shri Jeejeebhoy's decision in Dev Karan Nanjee Banking Co. v. Workmen, held entitled to allowance.
Bank manual: strong-room opened by Agent and second key-holder; funds withdrawn to shroff (paying-cum-receiving clerk) in single lock box; shroff handles cash during day, accounts to Agent at end.
In appeals 731-752, sole clerk keeps key of single lock box.
Shri Jeejeebhoy clarified under s.6 Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1955 that 'pay office' includes branches.

legal_issues.text: Whether application under s. 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act entertainable by Labour Court.
Whether para 164(b)(7) of Sastry Award applies to branches, not just pay offices.
Whether sole paying-cum-receiving clerk in branch is 'cashier in-charge of cash' under para 164(b)(7).

petitioner_arguments.text: Application not entertainable under s. 33C(2), Labour Court no jurisdiction.
Respondent at branch, not pay office, so not entitled under para 164(b)(7) Sastry Award.
No single person in-charge of cash; only Agent/second key-holder; respondent routine clerk handling cash but not in-charge.
Interpretation leads to anomalies, e.g., higher allowance than head cashiers in cl.4.
Labour Appellate Tribunal rejected allowance for receiving/paying cashiers (para 130).

respondent_arguments.text: Sole clerk in branch doing receiving and paying cash, in-charge entitling to Rs.15/- allowance under Sastry Award.

court_reasoning.text: Application maintainable per Central Bank of India v. P.S. Rajgopalan.
'Pay office' includes branches per Shri Jeejeebhoy clarification (Chairman of Labour Appellate Tribunal), unchallenged since 1959.
Sole paying-cum-receiving clerk (shroff) in-charge of cash in single lock during day; effective charge during transactions; higher responsibility than routine clerks.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sole clerk qualifies as cashier in-charge.

court_reasoning.text: Not overall charge of double lock (Agent/second key-holder), but single lock during working hours; clarification meaningful only thus.
Para 140 Labour Appellate Tribunal: pay appropriate allowances based on duties/responsibilities.
Routine clerks excluded unless sole in-charge; para 130 rejection for non-in-charge clerks.
No anomaly in higher allowance for sole in-charge vs. head cashier with subordinates.

holdings.text: Para 164(b)(7) Sastry Award's 'pay offices' includes branches.
Sole paying-cum-receiving clerk in branch, handling single lock cash during day, is 'cashier in-charge of cash' entitled to Rs.15/- allowance.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the banks' appeals, upholding Labour Court's orders granting special allowance of Rs.15/- per month to sole paying-cum-receiving clerks in branches under para 164(b)(7) of Sastry Award.
outcome.relief_granted: Employees entitled to special allowance as ordered by Labour Court

key_quotes.text: the sole receiving-cum-paying clerk is the person in-charge of the single lock throughout the day when transactions are going on in the bank.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'in-charge of cash' for allowance eligibility

key_quotes.text: when cl. 7 of para 164 b uses the words cashiers in-charge it refers to charge of cash in the single lock and not charge of cash in the double lock
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies scope of responsibility under Sastry Award

key_quotes.text: the clarification as it comes from such a tribunal should be accepted, particularly as it has stood unchallenged since it was given in 1959.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Accepts Jeejeebhoy's inclusion of branches in 'pay offices'
